Introduction

According to Britannica, globalization is “integration of the world’s economies, politics, and cultures”. A white paper issued by Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry states that the world's overall GDP has grown to $85.9 trillion as of 2019, about 60 times larger than it was in 1960. In the modern era, its effects can now be seen everywhere in the world, and this is especially true on the cultural front. It is often called “cultural globalization”.
In recent years there has been considerable controversy about the pros and cons of it. Globalization itself, which began in earnest at the beginning of the 20th century, has passed through the second and third waves since the end of World War II, and is now said to be in the era of Globalization 4.0. It often progresses from economic factors, but its impact is very far-reaching, and this applies to culture as well.
Globalization, therefore, has received various compliments and, to the contrary,  criticisms from the industry and academia dealing with culture and the humanities. A typical criticism is that traditional and minority cultures will disappear or their social status will decline. However, this assertion misses the mark. To see that it is wrong, one need only look at language policy throughout the history. In conservative contries where there is little flow of people and goods to and from other countries, there is extremely strong tendency for domestic minority cultures to be suppressed. Spain, for example, during the period of dictation, the minority languages like Basque, Catalonia and Galician were prohibited and all people were enforced to speak “pure” Spanish, Castilian. In Japan, too, the minority cultures and languages of Ryukyu Islands, the Ainu, and the Islands Department were heavily suppressed during the period of “Seculation”. Moreover, former colonies of Western powers, where a block economy was in place, were also forced to learn and use the languageof the suzerain state or 
However, at this time, the advantages of cultural globalization still outweigh the disadvantages. This paper will argue that more people and nations should be open to and accept globalization and different ideas and culture because it has promoted cross-cultural understanding and coexistence.
